review.title: Pose Estimation Based on 3D Models
review.abstract: In this paper, we proposed a pose estimation system based on rendered image training set, which predicts the pose of objects in real image, with knowledge of object category and tight bounding box. We developed a patch-based multi-class classification algorithm, and an iterative approach to improve the accuracy. We achieved state-of-the-art performance on pose estimation task.

metadata.title: Pose Estimation Based on 3D Models

sections.text: Pose Estimation based on 3D models Chuiwen Ma, Hao Su, Liang Shi

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This project aims to estimate the pose of an object in the image. Although it is an open problem and also a crucial problem in the field of computer visualization, many tasks in the real world depend heavily on it or can be improved by a good estimate. For example, robots will know where to sit, how to avoid a collision while walking, and the estimate is also applicable to automatic driving.

sections.heading: 1.1 Related Works
sections.text: In general, there are two typical lines of research: one based on 2D representation and the other on 3D information.Among 2D-based research, [6,7,8] is based on point matching, which is now obsolete. By linking diagnostic parts of the object from different angles, [9] an object category represents a collection of visual invariant regions. Sun et al. [10] and Su et al. [17] used a generative approach to group local features into parts and then learn sub-locations from different angles. [11] A SIFT-like [18] spatial pyramid of histograms have a feature to form an SVM classifier for each discrete pose. Inspired by the success of the deformable partial model [12], [13] trained a DPM using a semi-latent approach where the components coincide with discrete points of view.

sections.heading: 2.1 Training Data
sections.text: As we mentioned in Section 1, we gathered our training data from ShapeNet, an emerging 3D shape model database. With 9,135,135 semantically annotated 3D models across thousands of object categories, ShapeNet was able to provide ample information for many visual tasks. In our task, we used these 5,057 chair models in ShapeNet. For each model, we rendered it to 16 evenly distributed viewing angles on the horizontal circle shown in Figure 1. We selected 4,000 models, corresponding to 64,000 images, to create the training data set, and left the remaining 1,057 models as our rendered image test set (validation set). Before extracting the image features, we first resize the images to 112 x 112 pixels and then divide them into 6 x 6 overlapped patch grids, with patch size 32 x 32 and patch strips 16 on both axes. After preprocessing, we extract a 576-36-dimensional image that can be represented by any workout-dimensional Hock 7G feature.

sections.heading: 2.2 Test Data
sections.text: In order to comprehensively assess the performance of our learning algorithm, we have built three different test kits with increasing difficulty: rendered image test kits, real image test kits with clean backgrounds, and crowded test kits with real backgrounds. As already mentioned in paragraph 2.1, the rendered image test kits consist of 1057 x 16 rendered images, also from ShapeNet. Clean background and cluttered real image test kits are collected from ImageNet [3], which contains 1309 and 1000 images, respectively, both with manually labeled ground truth of view. Some sample images are shown in Figure 3. Obviously, these three data sets are increasingly noisy and therefore difficult to manipulate.For image preprocessing and the extraction of functions on the test kits, we used the same scheme as the train set, meaning that each image is converted into a 20736-dimensional HoG function.

sections.heading: 3 Model
sections.text: Instead of using the global image function as input for the classification, our Pose estimation model is patch based. By dividing the image into patches and creating a classifier for each patch, our model can be more resistant to occlusion and background noise. In addition, this approach reduced the feature dimension for each classifier, thus reducing sample complexity. In fact, we have tried global features, while the classification accuracy is 30% lower than the HoG function of the entire image, V = {1, · ·, V} as a discredited pose space. For each patch, we build a classifier that learns from the training data and predicts the conditional probability P (v | Fi).

sections.heading: 4 Methods
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Learning Algorithms
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1.1 Random Forest
sections.text: In this project, we chose random forest [1] as the primary classification algorithm based on its following advantages: • Suitable for classification with multiple classes. • Not parametric, easy to agree. • Fast, easy to parallel. • Robust due to randomized processing. During the classification, 36 random forest classifiers are trained for 36 fields. To balance spatial and temporal complexity and performance, we set the forest size to 100 trees. In addition, we set the maximum depth of the trees by means of cross-validation, with the optimal depth being 20. Consequently, each random forest produces a probability vector P (v | Fi). After smoothing Laplace, we calculated P (v | I), estimated the pose to v = arg maxv P (v | I).

sections.heading: 4.2 Optimization
sections.text: Building training data sets from rendered images has many advantages, but there are also disadvantages. As I mentioned in Section 1, the previous probability of a pose in real images can be very different from that in rendered images. As we know, the distribution of poses in the training set is uniform, but in real images there are many more chairs from the front than from the back. Fortunately, this difference can be analyzed and modeled as follows.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Parameter Automatic Selection
sections.text: After several iterations, the algorithm will converge, and we will obtain a definitive estimate P-point (v-point) of P-point (v-point). However, other α-points will lead to widely different convergent results, as in Figure 4. From the test results in Figure 5, we have observed that if α is too small, the point of view with the highest initial probability P-point (v-point) will soon take on a different point of view, and P-point (v-point) will converge to a completely distorted distribution. Whereas if α is too large, the smoothing effect is too strong to affect P-point (v-point), this results in P-point (v-point) = P-point (v-point). However, there is an intermediate value of α to maximize the accuracy of classification and lead to an optimal estimate P-point (v-point). In Figure 4 and 5, we will perform a deep analysis of the relationship between stable point-point (the P-point) and P-point (the P-point) curve.

sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 Classification Performance
sections.text: In Table 1, our patch-based random classification algorithm for forests (referred to as RF) often shows a promising classification result for all three sets of tests. According to our scheme, the random forest achieves 80% accuracy on a clean background and 77% accuracy on a crowded background. The relatively small improvement over the overcrowded test set could be due to our assumption that P (Fi | v) = P (Fi | v) and P (Fi) = P (Fi) are too strong for overcrowded images. The relatively small improvement over the overcrowded test set could be due to our assumption that P (Fi | v) = P (Fi | v) and P (Fi) = P (Fi) are too strong for overcrowded images.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this thesis, we proposed a novel approach to estimating poses - learn from 3D models. We explained our model in the Bayean framework and developed a new optimization method for transferring information from 2D images to 3D models. The promising experimental results confirmed the effectiveness of our scheme.

sections.heading: 7 Future Work
sections.text: We have several ideas for future work, which are described as follows: • Consider the foreground and background information in the image, make full use of the information in rendered images. • Continue to model the difference between three sets of data, revise our false assumptions. • Learn about the distinctiveness of patches, give different patches different weights. • Generalize our algorithm to hidden images or different categories to see what will happen.

By linking together diagnostic parts of object from different views, [9] represents an object category as a collection of view-invariant regions.
[17] used a generative approach to group local features into parts and then learn part locations across viewpoints.
[11] used a SIFT-like [18] spatial pyramids of histograms feature to train a SVM classifier for each discrete pose.

[15] used convolutional neural network features for the task of pose estimation.
[16] proposed a Hough Forest based method for simultaneous object detection and continuous pose estimation.
[19] extended deformable part models to 3D, where part appearances and spatial deformations are represented in 3D.
Using an readymade approach, [20] first obtained a rough localization and viewpoint of the object, and then estimated a continuous pose by using annotated 3D CAD models.
[21] estimated poses of cars using an explicit 3D shape model and viewpoint which is learned from structure-from-motion (SFM).
After preprocessing, we extract a 576 dimensional HoG feature [2] from each patch, so the whole image can be represented by a 20736 dimensional feature vector.
Clean background and cluttered background real image test sets are collected from ImageNet [3], containing 1309 and 1000 images respectively, both with manually labeled ground truth of viewpoint.
1 Random Forest In this project, we choose random forest [1] as a primary classification algorithm based on its following advantages: • Suitable for multiclass classification.

metadata.abstractText: This project aims to estimate the pose of an object in the image. Pose estimation problem is known to be an open problem and also a crucial problem in computer vision field. Many real-world tasks depend heavily on or can be improved by a good pose estimation. For example, by knowing the exact pose of an object, robots will know where to sit on, how to grasp, or avoid collision when walking around. Besides, pose estimation is also applicable to automatic driving. With good pose estimation of cars, automatic driving system will know how to manipulate itself accordingly. Moreover, pose estimation can also benefit image searching, 3D reconstruction and has a large potential impact on many other fields.
